Package org.jlab.epsci.ersap.std.orchestrators

Class OrchestratorConfigParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jlab.epsci.ersap.std.orchestrators.OrchestratorConfigParser
  • public class OrchestratorConfigParser
extends java.lang.Object
    Helper class to read configuration for the standard orchestrators.

    Currently, the user can set:

    • A default container name and language for the services
    • The set of I/O services (required)
    • The list of processing services (required)
    • The list of mime-types used by the services (required)
    • The global configuration for all services
    The services description is provided in a YAML file, which format is the following: 
     container: default # Optional: change default container, otherwise it is $USER
 io-services:
   reader:
     class: org.jlab.clas12.ana.ReaderService
     name: ReaderService
   reader:
     class: org.jlab.clas12.ana.WriterService
     name: WriterService
 services:
   - class: org.jlab.clas12.ana.ServiceA
     name: ServiceA
   - class: org.jlab.clas12.rec.ServiceB
     name: ServiceB
     container: containerB # Optional: change container for this service
   - class: service_c
     name: ServiceC
     lang: cpp # a C++ service
 mime-types:
   - binary/data-hipo
 config:
   param1: "some_string"
   param2:
      key1: 31
      key2: 50
    By default, all processing and I/O services will be deployed in a container named as the $USER running the orchestrator. This can be changed by including a container key with the desired container name. The container can be overwritten for individual services too. There is no need to include I/O services in this file. They are controlled by the orchestrators.

    • Method Detail

      • parseLanguages

        public java.util.Set<ErsapLang> parseLanguages()
        Returns the languages of all services defined in the application.
        Returns:
        a set with the languages of the services

      • parseDataTypes

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> parseDataTypes()
        Returns the mime-types required to receive messages from the services.

        The orchestrator will create fake EngineDataType objects for each mime-type. These will not deserialize the user-data contained in the messages, they will be used to access just the metadata.

        Returns:
        the mime-types of the data returned by the services
